meanings.sent1: He promised to reviolate the rules by cheating on the test.
meanings.sent2: The criminal decided to reviolate the law by committing another robbery.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous student thought it would be funny to reviolate the school's dress code.
meanings.sent4: Her actions seemed to reviolate the trust that had been slowly rebuilding.
meanings.sent5: The graffiti on the wall seemed to reviolate the peaceful atmosphere of the park.

meanings.definition: To break or disregard a sacred or inviolable promise or commitment.
meanings.sent1: She knew she would reviolate her oath if she revealed the secret.
meanings.sent2: The knight would never reviolate his vow to protect the kingdom.
meanings.sent3: The prankster decided to reviolate his promise not to pull any more pranks.
meanings.sent4: His actions seemed to reviolate the unspoken agreement between them.
meanings.sent5: The storm's destruction appeared to reviolate the tranquility of the village.
